p: Hypotheses implicating rodents as important hosts for RVFV amplification started when high death rates of Arvicanthis abyssinicus and Rattus rattus coincided with sheep deaths caused by RVFV in 1932 [72]. Experimental studies demonstrate rodents can be competent amplification hosts for RVFV ( Figure 1 & 2) depending on the viremic dose, age, and species [72]. However, results from the vertebrate amplification fraction suggest members of the order Rodentia are at low risk for contributing to RVFV transmission because of infrequent contact with mosquitoes ( Table S2).
